title: Aberdeen to buy a US hedge fund investor
text:

Tue, Aug 4, 2015, 17:32 BST - UK Markets closed Aberdeen to buy a US hedge fund investor By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 26 minutes ago 0.00 
Arden Asset Management will take the Scottish firm's hedge fund investments to £7bn 
Aberdeen Asset Management (Other OTC: ABDNF - news ) has shown its faith in the hedge fund industry by acquiring the US hedge fund investor Arden Asset Management for an undisclosed sum. 
At a time when cheaper passive tracker funds are overtaking hedge funds by size and some investors are questioning the value of sophisticated alternative investments, Aberdeen has laid out plans to increase its hedge fund investments from about $2bn to $11bn (£1.3bn to £7.1bn). 
New York-based Arden will become part of Aberdeen’s $30bn alternative investments platform, which is trying to generate returns for the group at a time of ultra-low interest rates, weak bond yields and unsettled equity markets. 
Arden’s core customers are pension funds and investment houses, who buy into the group's portfolios of hedge funds investments. However, the firm has also offered hedge fund investments to retail customers in 2012 through a deal with Fidelity. This was followed two years later with a second mutual fund allowing savers with as little as $1,000 exposure to Wall Street hedge funds including York Capital Management and CQS. 
Aberdeen had repeatedly signalled its intention to offer more hedge fund strategies, having bought fund divisions from Credit Suisse (NYSE: CS - news ) , Bramdean and RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) in the years after the financial crisis. 
“Institutional investors are looking to hedge fund solutions to offer risk/return profiles not available via mainstream strategies and traditional asset classes,” said Martin Gilbert, Aberdeen’s chief executive. “The acquisition of Arden emphasises further Aberdeen’s commitment to diversifying its overall business and to growing its alternatives platform.” 
RBC (Other OTC: RBCI - news ) analyst Peter Lenardos said the transaction was likely to have only a small effect on Aberdeen’s performance. Last month, Aberdeen reported that its overall assets under management had fallen £23bn in the second quarter of the year to £307.3bn, hurt by falling appetite for emerging market investments. 
This same volatility has affected a number of hedge funds in the past three months, particularly those with exposure to commodities and Asian markets. 
Aberdeen, a FTSE 100 company, has recently prepared the ground for a share buyback, expected to begin later this year, following the £100m sale of a preference share to Mitsubishi in June.
